column1: ;1860;3.89;262069;yes;['Classics', 'Science Fiction', 'Fiction', 'Adventure', 'Fantasy', 'France', 'Literature'];No synopsis available.;No review available.;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/33507.Twenty_Thousand_Leagues_Under_the_Sea;In 1866
column2: ships of various nationalities sight a mysterious sea monster
column3: which is speculated to be a gigantic narwhal. The U.S. government assembles an expedition in New York City to find and destroy the monster. Professor Pierre Aronnax
column4: a French marine biologist and the story's narrator
column5: is in town at the time and receives a last-minute invitation to join the expedition. Canadian whaler and master harpooner Ned Land and Aronnax's faithful manservant Conseil are also among the participants.

column1: The expedition leaves Brooklyn aboard the United States Navy frigate Abraham Lincoln
column2: then travels south around Cape Horn into the Pacific Ocean. After a five-month search ending off Japan
column3: the frigate locates and attacks the monster
column4: which damages the ship's rudder. Aronnax and Land are hurled into the sea
column5: and Conseil jumps into the water after them. They survive by climbing onto the ""monster""
column6: which
column7: they are startled to find
column8: is a futuristic submarine. They wait on the deck of the vessel until morning
column9: when they are captured and introduced to the submarine's mysterious constructor and commander

column1: The rest of the novel describes the protagonists' adventures aboard the Nautilus
column2: which was built in secrecy and now roams the seas beyond the reach of land-based governments. In self-imposed exile
column3: Captain Nemo seems to have a dual motivation — a quest for scientific knowledge and a desire to escape terrestrial civilization. Nemo explains that his submarine is electrically powered and can conduct advanced marine research; he also tells his new passengers that his secret existence means he cannot let them leave — they must remain on board permanently.

column1: They visit many oceanic regions
column2: some factual and others fictitious. The travelers view coral formations
column3: sunken vessels from the Battle of Vigo Bay
column4: the Antarctic ice barrier
column5: the transatlantic telegraph cable
column6: and the legendary underwater realm of Atlantis. They even travel to the South Pole and are trapped in an upheaval of an iceberg on the way back
column7: caught in a narrow gallery of ice from which they are forced to dig themselves out. The passengers also put on diving suits
column8: hunt sharks and other marine fauna with air guns in the underwater forests of Crespo Island
column9: and attend an undersea funeral for a crew member who died during a mysterious collision experienced by the Nautilus. When the submarine returns to the Atlantic Ocean
column10: a school of giant squid (""devilfish"") attacks the vessel and kills another crewman.

column1: The novel's later pages suggest that Captain Nemo went into undersea exile after his homeland was conquered and his family slaughtered by a powerful imperialist nation. Following the episode of the devilfish
column2: Nemo largely avoids Aronnax
column3: who begins to side with Ned Land. Ultimately
column4: the Nautilus is attacked by a warship from the mysterious nation that has caused Nemo such suffering. Carrying out his quest for revenge
column5: Nemo — whom Aronnax dubs an ""archangel of hatred"" — rams the ship below her waterline and sends her to the bottom
column6: much to the professor's horror. Afterward
column7: Nemo kneels before a portrait of his deceased wife and children
column8: then sinks into a deep depression.

column1: Circumstances aboard the submarine change drastically: watches are no longer kept
column2: and the vessel wanders about aimlessly. Ned becomes so reclusive that Conseil fears for the harpooner's life. One morning
column3: he announces that they are in sight of land and have a chance to escape. Professor Aronnax is more than ready to leave Captain Nemo
column4: who now horrifies him
column5: yet he is still drawn to the man. Fearing that Nemo's very presence could weaken his resolve
column6: he avoids contact with the captain. Before their departure
column7: the professor eavesdrops on Nemo and overhears him calling out in anguish
column8: ""O almighty God! Enough! Enough!"". Aronnax immediately joins his companions as they carry out their escape plans
column9: but as they board the submarine's skiff they realize that the Nautilus has seemingly blundered into the ocean's deadliest whirlpool
column10: the Moskenstraumen (more commonly known as the ""Maelstrom""). They escape and find refuge on an island off the coast of Norway. The submarine's ultimate fate remained unknown until the events of The Mysterious Island.";https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twenty_Thousand_Leagues_Under_the_Seas

column1: ;1950;3.9;7428;yes;['Science Fiction', 'Fiction', 'Aliens', 'Hard Science Fiction', 'Science Fiction Fantasy', 'Speculative Fiction', 'Adventure'];No synopsis available.;No review available.;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/525285.Mission_of_Gravity;The native protagonist

column3: captain of the sailing raft Bree
column4: is on a trading expedition to the equator. Prior to the story's opening
column5: a human scientific rocket has become stranded at one of the planet's poles
column6: where the gravity is too strong to effect a rescue. A member of the scientific team
column7: Charles Lackland
column8: is dispatched to the equator where he has met Barlennan by chance. Even machine aided
column9: Lackland is barely able to function in the 3 g environment
column10: one Barlennan considers incredibly light and a tiny fraction of what his culture is used to.

column1: Lackland teaches the Bree crew English and arranges a deal with Barlennan; in exchange for the humans providing warnings of the violent weather which often plagues trips to the pole
column2: Barlennan will help retrieve the recorded information from the rocket. Communication is achieved through an audio-visual radio built to function in a high-gravity environment
column3: which is treated as magical by other intelligences encountered on the planet.

column1: Along the way to the pole
column2: the ship encounters and overcomes a variety of obstacles
column3: some of which the humans help with using their superior scientific knowledge
column4: and some of which rely on the cunning of Barlennan and his crew. They are captured by various lifeforms similar to themselves
column5: but who live in the lower-gravity areas and have developed projectile weapons and gliders. Gradually
column6: with human help
column7: they gain an understanding of these and manage to escape.

column1: Barlennan has been dissatisfied with the humans' efforts to seemingly avoid explanation of anything scientific
column2: and almost withholds the rocket when they finally reach it; but the humans convince them that a scientific background is needed to understand the advanced equipment
column3: and a deal is reached whereby the humans will educate the Mesklinites.

column1: The novel provides an exposition on how the weather
column2: geology and atmosphere of the seas and the pole are affected by the local conditions
column3: and sees the Mesklinites overcoming their fear of gravity as they learn to view it scientifically
column4: eventually harnessing aerodynamics to make the Bree fly at the poles.";https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mission_of_Gravity

;1970;4.12;172926;yes;['Science Fiction', 'Fiction', 'Science Fiction Fantasy', 'Audiobook', 'Space', 'Classics', 'Novels'];No synopsis available.;No review available.;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/112537.Rendezvous_with_Rama;An asteroid strikes Italy in 2077
column2: prompting the creation of the Spaceguard system to track potentially hazardous objects in space. In 2131
column3: Spaceguard detects an interstellar object entering the Solar System
column4: designating it ""31/439"" before naming it Rama after the Hindu god. A space probe reveals that Rama is a perfectly smooth cylinder 50 kilometres (31 mi) long and 20 kilometres (12 mi) in diameter
column5: indicating that it was constructed by intelligent beings.

column1: Endeavour is sent to study Rama
column2: being the only ship close enough to do so. The crew navigates through a triple airlock system and descends one of three identical staircases. Inside Rama
column3: they discover two plains that stretch across the interior circumference
column4: divided by a frozen body of water they name the Cylindrical Sea. They identify several city-sized clusters of geometric structures
column5: which they name after major cities on Earth. The United Planets follows their progress closely
column6: and scientists are assembled to form a Rama Committee that considers theories and advises Commander Norton.

column1: As Rama drifts closer to the sun
column2: the Cylindrical Sea melts
column3: the temperature shift causes a storm
column4: and three massive lights activate on each plain to illuminate the world. Boris Rodrigo
column5: a crewman who adheres to a space-inspired sect of Christianity
column6: suggests that Rama is a new Noah's Ark that will change course to begin orbiting the sun. The crew floats across the Cylindrical Sea on a raft to reach an island they name New York
column7: and a sample of the water reveals the presence of microorganisms. The structures in New York are positioned in patterns of three
column8: without any openings
column9: and their purpose is unidentifiable.

column1: The crewman Jimmy Pak approaches Norton to admit that he smuggled a sky-bike onto their ship and offers to fly it above a cliff to reach the southern plain. He flies to the other end of Rama
column2: which is defined by a large spike several kilometers in length and surrounded by smaller spikes. Pak realizes that a static field is building around the spikes
column3: which then emits a concussion that knocks his sky-bike out of the air and destroys it
column4: stranding him in the southern plain. As he recovers from the crash
column5: a crab-like creature arrives to disassemble the sky-bike and dispose of its parts. Pak is unable to determine whether the creature is biological or robotic.

column1: Pak explores the patchwork terrain of the southern plain while he waits for rescue. He finds a single alien flower
column2: which he takes. A rescue crew arrives on the raft
column3: and Pak jumps from the cliff into the Cylindrical Sea so they can pull him aboard. A course change by Rama triggers a series of large waves
column4: but Sergeant Ruby Barnes navigates them to safety. They see a damaged starfish-like creature emerge from the sea
column5: and shark-like creatures arrive to disassemble it.

column1: After returning to their camp
column2: a spider-like creature with three eyes and three legs studies all of their equipment. More arrive
column3: and one falls from a higher platform to its destruction. Ernst takes the opportunity to dissect the creature and finds that it is both biological and robotic
column4: so they conclude that the creatures were designed by the Ramans and begin referring to them as biots. The government of Mercury
column5: having decided that Rama is too dangerous
column6: launches a nuclear weapon to destroy it. Rodrigo intercepts the missile and disarms it
column7: taking advantage of the 12-minute time lag for radio communication between it and Mercury.

column1: The crew prepares to evacuate as Rama gets too close to the sun. For their final expedition
column2: they visit a city with a laser and cut a hole into the side of a structure. Inside they find a collection of holograms that provide details on various Raman artefacts
column3: including a suit designed for a three-legged humanoid. As they leave
column4: the biots return to the sea to be disassembled and the lights begin to dim. The crew boards Endeavour and leaves Rama. Rama changes course to move directly toward the sun and moves alongside it to gather energy. It then activates a space drive to propel itself out of the Solar System in the direction of the Large Magellanic Cloud. After Rama leaves
column5: a member of the Rama Committee considers that the Ramans do everything in threes.";https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rendezvous_with_Rama

column1: ;1970;3.95;30796;no;['Science Fiction', 'Fiction', 'Hugo Awards', 'Classics', 'Science Fiction Fantasy', 'Audiobook', 'Space'];No synopsis available.;No review available.;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/149049.The_Fountains_of_Paradise;The novel focuses primarily on a project known as the Orbital Tower proposed by the main character
column2: Vannevar Morgan. The tower is to stretch from the Earth's equator to a satellite that is in geostationary orbit. Such a structure would greatly reduce the cost of sending people and supplies into space.

column1: The main story is framed by two other stories. The first one tells of King Kalidasa
column2: living thousands of years before Morgan is born
column3: who is constructing a 'pleasure garden' complete with functioning fountains
column4: in a significant engineering effort for the time. The other story
column5: taking place long after Morgan has died
column6: deals with aliens making contact with Earth.

column1: Due to many technical issues
column2: there are only two locations on Earth where the Orbital Tower can be built. One is in the middle of the Pacific Ocean
column3: and the other is Sri Kanda (a thinly veiled reference to Adam's Peak in Sri Lanka). However
column4: there is a Buddhist temple on the island
column5: and Mahanayake Thero
column6: the head of the order
column7: refuses to give permission to begin construction.

column1: Hearing of the difficulties
column2: a group of people living on Mars contacts Morgan and suggests that the tower be built there instead. It would be smaller than the one planned for Earth
column3: and would reach from Mars to one of its moons
column4: Deimos.

column1: After a few setbacks
column2: including some fatalities
column3: construction of the tower gets underway. Although the engineer's heart is failing
column4: he rides up the tower to take food and oxygen to a group of stranded students and their professor. After overcoming serious difficulties he succeeds
column5: then dies of a heart attack on the way back down.";https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Fountains_of_Paradise

;1980;4.15;146722;no;['Science Fiction', 'Fiction', 'Classics', 'Science Fiction Fantasy', 'Space', 'Audiobook', 'Fantasy'];No synopsis available.;No review available.;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/53000876-contact;As a child
column2: Eleanor ""Ellie"" Arroway shows a strong aptitude for science and mathematics. Dissatisfied with a school lesson
column3: she confirms in a library that pi is transcendental. In sixth grade
column4: her father
column5: Theodore (""Ted"")
column6: dies. Her new stepfather
column7: John Staughton
column8: does not support her interests. Ellie resents him and believes her mother remarried out of weakness.

column1: After graduating from Harvard
column2: Ellie earns a doctorate from Caltech under radio astronomer David Drumlin. She becomes director of ""Project Argus
column3: a New Mexico radio telescope array searching for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI). This puts her at odds with much of the scientific community
column4: including Drumlin
column5: who pushes to defund SETI. Eventually
column6: the project detects a signal from Vega
column7: 26 light-years away
column8: transmitting prime numbers. Further analysis reveals a retransmission of Adolf Hitler’s 1936 Olympic speech
column9: the first TV signal to escape Earth’s ionosphere.

column1: President Helen Lasker meets with Ellie to discuss first contact. Ellie begins a relationship with Presidential Science Advisor Ken der Heer. With Soviet colleague Vaygay Lunacharsky
column2: she ensures continuous monitoring of the signal. A third message contains plans for an advanced machine
column3: but decoding its 30
column4: 000 pages proves impossible without a missing primer.

column1: At the President’s insistence
column2: Ellie meets religious leaders Billy Jo Rankin and Palmer Joss. A skeptic
column3: she demonstrates her faith in science by trusting a Foucault pendulum. Dismissing Rankin’s views
column4: she finds Joss’s perspective intriguing. In Paris
column5: experts confirm the Machine is a five-seat dodecahedron. There
column6: Ellie meets Devi Sukhavati
column7: a doctor who lost her husband after leaving India for love. The final message piece is found when billionaire S. R. Hadden suggests checking for phase modulation
column8: revealing the primer.

column1: A U.S.-Soviet race to build the Machine ensues
column2: but Soviet design flaws leave the American version as the only option. Ellie applies as a passenger but loses her spot to Drumlin. Extremists plant a bomb in the Wyoming facility
column3: which detonates during testing
column4: killing Drumlin and delaying the project indefinitely. Meanwhile
column5: Ellie’s mother suffers a stroke
column6: leaving her paralyzed. Staughton accuses Ellie of neglecting her family.

column1: Ellie later learns Hadden has moved to a private space station. There
column2: he reveals his company has secretly built a third Machine in Hokkaido
column3: Japan
column4: set for launch on December 31
column5: 1999. Ellie
column6: Vaygay
column7: and Devi secure seats
column8: joined by Nigerian physicist Abonnema Eda and Chinese archaeologist Xi Qiaomu. Before departure
column9: Joss gives Ellie a medallion

column1: The activated Machine transports the group through wormholes to a station near the Milky Way’s center
column2: where each meets an extraterrestrial in the form of a loved one. Ellie’s visitor
column3: appearing as Ted
column4: explains their species’ motives and a project to alter the universe’s properties using mass in Cygnus A. The wormhole network was built by unknown precursors
column5: and hidden messages exist in transcendental numbers like pi. Reunited
column6: the travelers record evidence before the dodecahedron returns them to Earth.

column1: Back home
column2: their journey—seeming more than a day—took no time at all on Earth. Their video recordings are erased
column3: likely by wormhole magnetic fields. With Hadden seemingly dead and the transmission halted
column4: officials suspect a hoax. Pressured
column5: the travelers stay silent
column6: though Joss believes Ellie
column7: who now relies on faith. The novel later reveals Hadden faked his death
column8: secretly launching himself into space using cryogenics
column9: but this remains unknown to the characters.

column1: Following ""Ted’s"" suggestion
column2: Ellie runs a program computing pi to unprecedented lengths. Before results emerge
column3: her mother dies
column4: leaving a final letter revealing Staughton—not Ted—is Ellie’s biological father. When Ellie examines the program’s output
column5: she finds a circle formed from 0s and 1s after 1020 digits in pi’s base-11 representation—evidence of her journey.";https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contact_(novel)

;1990;4.11;990327;yes;['Science Fiction', 'Fiction', 'Thriller', 'Fantasy', 'Horror', 'Adventure', 'Classics'];No synopsis available.;No review available.;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/40604658-jurassic-park;In 1989
column2: strange animal attacks occur throughout Costa Rica. One of the species behind the attacks is believed to be Procompsognathus
column3: an extinct dinosaur. Paleontologist Alan Grant and his paleobotanist colleague Ellie Sattler are contacted to confirm the animal's identity
column4: but are abruptly whisked away by billionaire John Hammond
column5: the founder of bioengineering firm InGen
column6: for a weekend visit to a ""biological preserve"" he has established on Isla Nublar
column7: near Costa Rica.

column1: The ""preserve"" is a cover for the construction of Jurassic Park
column2: a theme park showcasing living dinosaurs. Construction is nearly complete; the dinosaurs have been recreated using ancient DNA found in the blood inside insects that were fossilized and preserved in amber. Gaps in the genetic code were filled in with reptilian
column3: avian
column4: or amphibian DNA. All dinosaurs are engineered to be female
column5: to prevent unauthorized breeding.

column1: The recent attacks have made Hammond's investors skittish. Hammond requests that Grant and Sattler tour the park and endorse it ahead of the park's opening. They are joined by mathematician and chaos theorist Ian Malcolm
column2: and a lawyer representing the investors
column3: Donald Gennaro: both of whom are pessimistic about the park. Malcolm
column4: consulted before the park's creation
column5: is emphatic that the park will collapse. Hammond also invites his grandchildren
column6: Tim and Alexis 'Lex' Murphy
column7: to join the tour. The park staff present comprise engineer John Arnold
column8: biotechnologist Henry Wu
column9: game warden Robert Muldoon
column13: and several laborers. While touring the park
column15: seemingly proving Malcolm's assertion that the dinosaurs are breeding against the geneticists' design. Grant deduces that using frog DNA to fill gaps in the dinosaurs' genetic code resulted in an environment that was conducive to dichogamy
column16: causing some of the female dinosaurs to become males and establish a breeding population. The park's automated computer tally failed to include newborns
column17: having been programmed to stop counting once the expected total number of animals was found.

column1: Nedry
column2: disgruntled with Hammond due to the latter's pushing out-of-scope work in developing the park's software systems
column3: commits corporate espionage for Lewis Dodgson: an employee of InGen's rival Biosyn. Activating a backdoor he wrote into the park's software
column4: he disables the security systems and steals frozen embryos for the park's fifteen dinosaur species. Attempting to rendezvous with Dodgson's agent
column5: he becomes lost due to a tropical storm. Without Nedry to reactivate the park's systems
column6: the dinosaurs can roam freely due to electric fences being turned off. He is killed by a Dilophosaurus
column7: and a Tyrannosaurus rex attacks the tour group. Grant saves the children before escaping with them into the jungle
column8: Regis is killed by a juvenile T. rex
column9: and Malcolm is gravely injured but rescued by Muldoon and Gennaro.

column1: The park staff try rebooting the park's computers to reverse Nedry's sabotage but fail to notice that only the auxiliary power generator restarts. Its fuel supply soon runs out
column2: again shutting down the park. The park's intelligent and aggressive Velociraptors escape their enclosure before killing Arnold and Wu. Grant and the children make their way back to the island's control complex by rafting down a jungle river
column3: narrowly escaping multiple dinosaur attacks. Grant turns on the park's main generators
column4: and Tim reactivates the park's systems. Gennaro recalls a supply boat traveling from the island to the mainland
column5: acting on the suspicions of Grant and the children that dinosaurs are aboard.

column1: Hammond
column2: walking outdoors while contemplating InGen's future
column3: is killed by a pack of Procompsognathus after he falls down a hill and breaks his ankle. Grant
column4: Sattler
column5: Muldoon
column6: and Gennaro find the wild raptor nests and compare hatched eggs with the island's revised population tally
column7: before realizing that raptors are attempting to migrate off the island.

column1: Malcolm dies from his injuries. Everyone is evacuated by the Costa Rican Air Force
column2: which declares the dinosaurs hazardous and razes the island with napalm. The survivors are detained in a Costa Rican hotel. Weeks later
column3: Grant is visited by Dr. Martin Gutierrez: an American doctor who lives in Costa Rica. Gutierrez informs Grant that an unknown pack of animals has been migrating through the Costa Rican jungle
column4: indicating that dinosaurs have escaped the island and returned to Earth's ecosystem.";https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jurassic_Park_(novel)

;2000;4.01;46769;yes;['Science Fiction', 'Fiction', 'Horror', 'Vampires', 'Aliens', 'Fantasy', 'Audiobook'];No synopsis available.;No review available.;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/48484.Blindsight;In the year 2082
column2: tens of thousands of coordinated comet-like objects of an unknown origin
column3: dubbed ""Fireflies""
column4: burn up in the Earth's atmosphere in a precise grid
column5: while momentarily broadcasting across an immense portion of the electromagnetic spectrum
column6: catching humanity off guard and alerting it to an undeniable extraterrestrial presence. It is suspected that the entire planet has been surveyed in one effective sweep. Despite the magnitude of this ""Firefall""
column7: human politics soon return to normal.

column1: Soon afterwards
column2: a comet-surveying satellite stumbles across a radio transmission originating from a comet
column3: subsequently named 'Burns-Caulfield'. This tight-beam broadcast is directed to an unknown location and in fact does not intersect the Earth at any point. As this is the first opportunity to learn more about the extraterrestrials
column4: three waves of ships are sent out: the first being lightweight probes shot out for an as-soon-as-possible flyby of the comet
column5: then a wave of heavier but better-equipped probes
column6: and finally a crewed ship
column7: the Theseus.

column1: Theseus is propelled by an antimatter reactor and captained by an artificial intelligence. It carries a crew of five cutting-edge transhuman hyper-specialists
column2: of whom one is a genetically reincarnated vampire who acts as the nominal mission commander. While the crew is in hibernation en route
column3: the just-arrived second wave of probes commence a compounded radar scan of the subsurface of Burns-Caulfield
column4: but this immediately causes the object to self-destruct. Theseus is re-routed mid-flight to the new-found destination of the signal: a previously undetected sub-brown dwarf deep in the Oort cloud
column5: dubbed 'Big Ben'.

column1: The crew wakes from hibernation while the Theseus closes on Big Ben. They discover a giant
column2: concealed object in the vicinity
column3: and assume it to be a vessel of some kind. As soon as the crew uncloaks the vessel
column4: it immediately hails them over radio and
column5: in a range of languages varying from English to Chinese
column6: identifies itself as 'Rorschach'. They determine that Rorschach must have learned human languages by eavesdropping on comm-chatter since its arrival
column7: sometime after the Broadcast Age began. Over the course of a few days many questions and answers are exchanged by both parties. Eventually Susan James
column8: the linguist
column9: determines that 'Rorschach' does not really understand what either party is actually saying.

column1: Theseus probes Rorschach and finds it to have hollow sections
column2: some with atmosphere
column3: all filled with levels of radiation that render remote operation of machinery virtually impossible and would kill a human in a matter of hours. Despite this and over Rorschach's objections the whole crew except the mission commander enters and explores in a series of short forays
column4: using the ship's advanced medical facilities to recover from the damage the radiation inflicts on their bodies. They discover the presence of highly evasive
column5: fast-moving nine-legged organisms dubbed 'Scramblers'. They kill one and capture two for study. The 'Scramblers' appear to have orders of magnitude more brainpower than human beings but use most of it simply to operate their fantastically complex musculature and sensory organs; they are more akin to something like white blood cells in a human body. They are dependent on the radiation and EM fields of Rorschach for basic biological functions and seem to completely lack consciousness.

column1: The crew explore questions of identity
column2: the nature
column3: utility and interdependence of intelligence and consciousness. They theorize that humanity could be an unusual offshoot of evolution
column4: wasting bodily and economic resources on the self-aware ego which has little value in terms of Darwinian fitness. Open warfare breaks out between the humans and the Scramblers and Theseus eventually decides to sacrifice itself and its crew using its antimatter payload to eliminate Rorschach. One crew member
column5: the protagonist and narrator Siri Keeton
column6: is shot off inside an escape vessel in a decades-long fall back to Earth to relay the crucial information amassed back to humanity. As he travels back towards the inner Solar System
column7: he hears radio broadcasts which suggest that the vampires have revolted and may be exterminating baseline humanity.";https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blindsight_(Watts_novel)

column1: The Martian;Andy Weir;2011;"""The Martian"" centers on astronaut Mark Watney's struggle for survival after being stranded on Mars during a NASA mission in 2035. The story emphasizes his ingenuity and resourcefulness as he uses his scientific knowledge to overcome numerous challenges
column2: including growing food
column3: finding water
column4: and establishing communication with Earth. The setting is primarily the Martian landscape
column5: specifically the Acidalia Planitia and Schiaparelli crater. Secondary characters include the Ares 3 crew
column6: particularly Commander Melissa Lewis

column25: reflecting a minor ecological message.;"""The Martian"" centers on astronaut Mark Watney's struggle for survival after being stranded on Mars during a NASA mission in 2035. column1: ;2010;4.42;1176318;yes;['Science Fiction', 'Fiction', 'Audiobook', 'Adventure', 'Space', 'Adult', 'Thriller'];No synopsis available.;No review available.;https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/18007564-the-martian;In the year 2035
column2: the crew of NASA's Ares 3 mission have arrived at Acidalia Planitia for a planned month-long stay on Mars. After only six sols
column3: an intense dust and wind storm threatens to topple their Mars Ascent Vehicle (MAV)
column4: which would trap them on the planet. During the hurried evacuation
column5: an antenna tears loose and impales astronaut Mark Watney
column6: a botanist and engineer
column7: also disabling his spacesuit radio. He is flung out of sight by the wind and presumed dead. As the MAV teeters dangerously
column8: mission commander Melissa Lewis has no choice but to take off without completing the search for Watney.

column1: However
column2: Watney is not dead. His injury proves relatively minor
column3: but with no long-range radio
column4: he cannot communicate with anyone. He must rely on his own resourcefulness to survive. He begins a log of his experiences. His philosophy is to ""work the problem""
column5: solving each challenge in turn as it confronts him. With food a critical
column6: though not immediate
column7: problem
column8: he begins growing potatoes in the crew's Martian habitat
column9: the Hab. He uses an iridium catalyst to separate hydrogen gas from surplus hydrazine fuel
column10: which he then burns to generate water for the plants.

column1: NASA eventually discovers that Watney is alive when satellite images of the landing site show evidence of his activities; NASA personnel begin devising ways to rescue him
column2: but withhold the news of his survival from the rest of the Ares 3 crew
column3: on their way back to Earth aboard the Hermes spacecraft
column4: so as not to distract them.

column1: Watney plans to drive 3
column3: 010 mi) to Schiaparelli crater where the next mission
column4: Ares 4
column5: will land in four years and whose MAV is already pre-positioned. He begins modifying one of the rovers for the journey
column6: adding solar cells and an additional battery. He makes a three-week test drive to recover part of the Pathfinder lander and Sojourner rover and brings it back to the Hab
column7: enabling him to contact NASA. Mitch Henderson
column8: the Ares 3 flight director
column9: convinces NASA Administrator Teddy Sanders to allow him to inform the Ares 3 crew of Watney's survival; they are thrilled
column11: who is guilt‑stricken at leaving him behind.

column1: The canvas at one of the Hab airlocks tears because of Watney's repeated use of the same airlock
column2: which was not designed for frequent and long‑term usage. This results in the depressurization of the Hab and nearly kills him. He repairs the Hab
column3: but his plants are dead
column4: threatening him again with eventual starvation. Setting aside safety protocols to comply with time constraints
column5: NASA hastily prepares an uncrewed probe to send Watney supplies
column6: but the rocket disintegrates after liftoff. A deal with the China National Space Administration provides a ready booster — planned for use with the Taiyang Shen
column7: an uncrewed solar probe — to try again. With no time to build a probe with a soft-landing system
column8: NASA is faced with the prospect of building a capsule whose cargo can survive crashing into the Martian surface at 300 meters per second (670 mph).

column1: However
column2: astrodynamicist Rich Purnell devises a ""slingshot"" trajectory around Earth for a gravity assist that could get Hermes back to Mars on a much-extended mission to save Watney
column3: using the Chinese rocket booster to send a simpler resupply probe to Hermes as it passes Earth. Sanders vetoes the ""Rich Purnell Maneuver""
column4: as it would entail risking the other crewmembers
column5: but Henderson secretly emails the details to Hermes. All five of Watney's crewmates approve the plan. Once they begin the maneuver
column6: having disabled the remote overrides
column7: NASA has no choice but to support them. The resupply ship docks with Hermes successfully.

column1: Watney resumes modifying the rover because the new rescue plan requires him to lift off from Mars in the Ares 4 MAV. While working on the rover
column2: Watney accidentally shorts out the electronics of Pathfinder
column3: losing the ability to communicate with Earth
column4: except for spelling out Morse code with rocks for a one-way communication.

column1: After Watney leaves for Schiaparelli
column2: NASA discovers that a dust storm is approaching his path
column3: but has no way to warn him. The rover's solar cells will be less and less able to recharge
column4: endangering both the rendezvous and his immediate survival if there is not enough power to run his life-support equipment. While crossing Arabia Terra
column5: Watney becomes aware of the darkening sky and improvises a rough measurement of the storm's shape and direction of movement
column6: enabling him to go around it.

column1: Surviving a rover rollover on his descent into Schiaparelli
column2: Watney reaches the MAV and reestablishes contact with NASA. He receives instructions on the radical modifications necessary to reduce the MAV's weight to enable it to intercept Hermes during its flyby. The modifications include removing the front of the MAV
column3: which Watney has to cover with Hab canvas. After takeoff
column4: the canvas tears
column5: creating extra drag and leaving the MAV too low for the rendezvous.

column1: Lewis hastily improvises a plan to intercept the MAV by firing Hermes' attitude thrusters and then blowing a hole in the front airlock with an improvised sugar-and-liquid-oxygen bomb
column2: using the thrust from the escaping air to reduce speed. Beck
column3: the Hermes' EVA specialist
column4: uses a Manned Maneuvering Unit
column5: MMU
column6: on a tether to reach Watney and bring him back to Hermes. In a final log entry
column7: Watney expresses his joy at being rescued
column8: reflecting on the human instinct to help those in need.";https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Martian_(Weir_novel)
